resources.string: Makes it easier to take clean screenshots by displaying a generic, preset notification bar that does not show notifications or low battery warnings

Displays color-coding on your device so you can visualize how how many times the same pixel has been drawn in the same frame. The visualization shows where your app might be doing more rendering than necessary
Show Layout Bounds to show your app\'s clip bounds, margins, and other user interface constructions on the device
Forces screen layout direction to be from right to left (RTL) or from left to right (default)
The Profile GPU Rendering tool displays, as a scrolling histogram, a visual representation of how much time it takes to render the frames of a UI window relative to a benchmark of 16ms per frame
ADB over network option helps to connect your device to ADB bridge without the need for USB cable
Caffeine was a simple tile in your Quick Settings panel that you could switch on to keep you screen on for at least five minutes after being idle
Show taps to display taps when you touch the screen
Sets the animator playback speed so you can check its performance at different speeds. A lower scale results in a faster speed
StrictMode is a developer tool which detects things you might be doing by accident and brings them to your attention so you can fix them
Enable USB debugging (figure 3) so your Android device can communicate with your development machine through Android Debug Bridge (adb)
Getting set up is super easy.
Please grant SU permission in order to gather \"magic\" permissions
Some QS tiles (like Demo mode) require these permissions to work
Congrats!\nYou can add some tiles now
Pull down your quick settings panel and click edit button to add some tiles
Everything\'s set up!\nLet\'s start development job :D
And don\'t forget to give us 5★
Don\'t be worried to tap Skip\nMost of the tiles will work perfectly without these permissions
Follow the next step to add tiles to your quick settings panel
